sub_title: PhD | Senior Artificial Intelligence Architect at OPT/NET BV
summary:
I obtained my PhD in Computer Vision and Machine Learning from University of Amsterdam under the supervision of Prof. Theo Gevers.

My PhD work explores physics-aware learning of intrinsic images; reflectance (albedo) and illumination (shading) by steering the learning processes of deep CNNs by physics-based reflection models and physics-based invariant descriptors. We demonstrate how to combine existing laws into the design of machine learning models. You can access the thesis using this link
https://dare.uva.nl/search?identifier=01b2d7ed-d0b2-4bf5-abd7-89a5d9b55a1c

During the process, we published our work in top conferences such as CVPR, ECCV, ICCV, BMVC and in top journals such as IJCV and CVIU. You can check the publications using this link
https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=mc4l2J4AAAAJ&hl=en

I am also experienced (and published research) in semantic segmentation, instance segmentation, surface normal estimation, illumination estimation, color constancy, optical flow, edge detection, generative models, and also traditional image processing and machine learning.

I have BSc in Computer Engineering and MSc in Data Engineering with a minor degree in Industrial Management. During my studies I interned in Microsoft and performed my MSc thesis work with Intel focusing on the camera image processing pipeline and low-level vision. I am comfortable with Python, Tensorflow, Matlab, C++ and familiar with SQL, Java, Caffe, OOP and software design patterns so that I can combine the research skills with software engineering practices.

projects: [{'title': 'URL-checking Service for Authenticated Users', 'date': {'start': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'description': 'The project aims to implement a concurrent URL-checking service for authenticated users. BSD/POSIX Socket programming interface is used in the network communication part and SHA-256 is used in authentication.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Anil', 'last_name': 'Baslamisli', 'name': None, 'headline': 'PhD | Senior Artificial Intelligence Architect at OPT/NET BV'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Peng', 'last_name': 'Yao', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Senior Software Designer'}]}, {'title': 'Insight: Big Data Analytics with Hadoop', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}, 'end': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}}, 'description': 'Big Data analytics provides opportunities to discover deeper, more complete business insights through the analysis and visualization of significant volumes of rapidly changing structured and unstructured data.  Traditional business intelligence systems struggle to analyze big data because they were designed for the analysis of relatively small amounts of structured data and simply cannot easily analyze unstructured data, large data sets or data sources that change quickly.
